entry.title: Combined summary - Dust recycling
entry.summary: On March 29th, 2014, a group of BitCoin enthusiasts had discussions about the issue of dust transactions. Brian C. Goss suggested collecting dust into a transaction with no outputs or putting it in an anyone can spend transaction, which raised concerns about the large number of signatures and transaction size. Another individual proposed a standard output type for sending the entire transaction to miner fees, allowing even large transactions to propagate that would normally be dropped by fee/kB rules. Justus Ranvier also suggested the need for a universal solution, proposing the idea of a "return operator" output type, while another user suggested using "dust-b-gone" to relay such transactions as someone else's problem. However, this solution was considered sub-optimal due to the introduction of a third party and possible server downtime issues. Instead, Ranvier emphasized the efficiency of aggregating multiple bits of dust in single transactions, although miners are unlikely to prioritize these transactions over those with higher fees per byte. The discussions also included a call to support online privacy by using email encryption whenever possible, with attachments for an encrypted key and signature.
